quote: we screened a known mutation(s) that could confer multidrug resistance to the currently approved NAIs ... by assessing recombinant viruses with mutant NA-encoding genes ... framework residues E119A/D/G ... Of the 14 single and double mutant viruses recovered in the backbone of pH1N1, four variants (E119D, E119A/D/G-H274Y) exhibited reduced inhibition by all of the NAIs and two variants (E119D and E119D-H274Y) retained the overall properties of gene stability, replicative efficiency, pathogenicity, and transmissibility in vitro and in vivo.
oseltamivir-resistant variants with the H274Y mutation developed in almost all seasonal H1N1 inﬂuenza virus strains between the 2007 and 2009 seasons ( 12).

we generated various recombinant influenza viruses with mutations in catalytic residues R152K and R292K and framework residues E119A/D/G, D198N, H274Y, and N294S in the pH1N1 and H5N1 backgrounds ... We tested each single and double mutant virus for sensitivity to oseltamivir, zanamivir, and peramivir

Multidrug-Resistant Influenza Virus Strains... E119D ... aShown is the NAI concentration that reduced NA activity by 50% relative to that in the reaction mixture containing the virus but no inhibitor. Values were obtained from three independent experiments...
the H274Y mutation conferred highly reduced inhibition by oseltamivir (1,131.4-fold IC50 increase). Also, the H274Y mutation reduced inhibition by peramivir by 50.6-fold.
The H274Y mutation in H5N1 conferred moderately reduced inhibition by oseltamivir (44.3-fold IC50 increase), although the mutation conferred highly reduced inhibition in the pH1N1 background.
The replication rate of the E119A mutant was slightly higher than that of parental pH1N1 at 48 hpi, although the peak titers of the two strains were similar at 72hpi.

Four single mutant (E119A, R152K, H274Y, and R292K) and two double mutant (E119D-H274Y and E119G-H274Y) variants in the pH1N1 backbone retained their growth properties in the lungs of infected mice at 3 and 6 dpi (within /H110061 log 10TCID50 compared with parental pH1N1; Table 3 ).
Two multidrug-resistant E119D and E119D-H274Y pH1N1 variants were evaluated for their pathogenic potential and transmissibility in ferrets because their viral fitness was comprehensively retained.

full- length sequencing of passaged NA mutants revealed that the E119G, R292K, and E119G-H274Y mutations in the pH1N1 background reverted after the in vitro passages ... but many of the mutant viruses can maintain their induced mutations that are associated with drug resistance

the E119D mutation, which conferred resistance to all of the NAIs, led to impaired viral replicative fitness in the pH1N1 background, the E119D mutant retained its growth properties and pathogenicity in mice.
E119 mutations conferred reduced susceptibility mainly to zana-mivir, suggesting that selective pressure is exerted by zanamivir in the N1 subtype.

effect: Decreased viral fitness in vitro and in vivo
quote: On the other hand, the E119D mutation conferred resistance to all of the NAIs, mainly to zanamivir ( Table 1 ), with slightly reduced viral fitness in vitro and in vivo (Fig. 1A and Table 3). In particular, the E119D mutation conferred a dramatically increased resistance to the inhibitor.
The E119D mutation was also associated with resistance to all of the NAIs, though it was not as high as that of the E119D-H274Y mutant.
